title: 112_hr6135
content: The Act titled "Transferring Credits for College Completion Act of 2012" requires data reporting. The Act "Transferring Credits for College Completion Act of 2012" mandates reporting transfer completion data for degree- or certificate-seeking undergraduate students. The Act "Transferring Credits for College Completion Act of 2012" requires reporting transfer completion data for undergraduate students, with a time limit of 200 percent of the normal completion time for the program. This section will take effect one year after the Act's enactment. SEC. 3. ARTICULATION AGREEMENTS. Section 485(h) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include transfer of credit policies, requiring institutions to indicate if courses are transferable for credit towards a degree at a public institution in the same state. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include transfer of credit policies, requiring institutions to have articulation agreements with other public institutions in the same state for transferable credits towards degree requirements. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include transfer of credit policies, requiring institutions to have articulation agreements with other public institutions in the same state for transferable credits towards degree requirements. This includes common course numbering for similar courses in the general education core curriculum and guarantees transferability of associate degrees towards related baccalaureate programs at public institutions in the state. Tribal colleges and universities are exempt from these requirements. Tribal Colleges or Universities are exempt from articulation agreements required for transfer of credit policies under the Higher Education Act of 1965. This exemption does not allow the Secretary or the National Advisory Committee to impose specific policies on higher education institutions regarding credit transfer, curriculum, or accreditation. It also does not limit the General Education Provisions Act or mandate control over educational institutions. The Higher Education Act of 1965 does not allow the imposition of specific policies on credit transfer, curriculum, or accreditation by the Secretary or the National Advisory Committee. It also does not limit the General Education Provisions Act or mandate control over educational institutions. Amendments to the Act include provisions on articulation agreements that meet certain requirements. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 include provisions on comprehensive articulation agreements and section 485(h)(2).
